The Prime Minister referred to the prospect of international discussions during the coming months on a variety of problems and sait that, for this and other reasons, it would be helpful if there could be a Conference at an early, date of Primes Ministers or other Ministers representing the Governments of the British Commonwealth and Empire.
The view of the War Cabinet was that the time was ripe for holding such a Conference, and that there would be substantial advantages if this could be held some time in the coming summmer, possibly in June or July. Every effort should be made to persuade the Ministers of Dominion Governments to come to London for such a Conference. It was recognised that some of the Dominion Prime Ministers might find it impracticable to travel to this country at the present time, but it might be possible for these to send a special representative qualified to speak on their behalf.
Preliminary enquiries of Dominion Government should be made at once.
The War Cabinet-
Invited the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs to communicate at once with Dominion Governments, in the light of the discussion, to ascertain whether it would be practicable to arrange for such a Conference to be held during the course of the coming summer.
The Secretary of State for India should be kept in touch with the course of these enquiries so that, at an appropriate stage, a similar enquiry could be addressed to the Government of India.
Town and Country Planning (Interim Development) Bill.
2. The War Cabinet had before them Memoranda on this subject by the Minister of Town and Country Planning (W.P.(43) 111), the Home Secretary (W.P. (43) 117), and the Lord President of the Council (W.P. (43) 132).
The objects of the Bill were-
(a) To extend planning control throughout England and
(b) To strengthen control over interim development while planning schemes were being prepared.
The Legislation Committee* had approved the terms of the Bill, subject to decision by higher authority on the questions:
(i) Was it expedient to proceed with planning legislation by stages, beginning with his limited measures, or would it be preferable to wait until comprehensive legislation could be introduced making radical changes in the system of planning?
(ii) If legislation was to be introduced amending the Town and Country Planning Acts, should not this opportunity be taken to confine the planning functions of Local Authorities to the Councils of Countries and County Boroughs?
These issues had been discussed by the Lord President's Committee on the 25th March. The majority of Ministers had taken the view that the balance of advantage lay on the side of proceeding with the Bill, but had referred the matter for final decision by the War Cabinet.
In discussion in the War Cabinet, the following were the main arguments advanced in favour of proceeding with legislation on the lines of the draft Bill:-
(a) Control over interim development needed to be strengthened at once, in order to prevent the position from being further prejudiced.
